entry.title: My List of Useful Ruby Gems
entry.content:
Useful list of Ruby gems that I frequently use in web development projects.

Front End Frameworks

  • Zurb Foundation - Uses SASS
  • Twitter Bootstrap - Uses LESS

Markup/Styling

  • HAML - Prettify your HTML. Looks much cleaner than erb.
  • SASS - Avoid spaghetti CSS. Uses SASS today.
  • Font-Awesome - Icon-fonts

Forms

  • Simple Form - Form generator: labels, error states, dropdowns, checkboxes, etc

Error Reporting

  • Better Errors - Meaningful error screens
  • Rails Panel - Show Rails app requests in Chrome Dev Tool

Authentication

  • Devise - THE authentication system for Rails

Authorization

  • Omniauth - Login with Facebook, Twitter, g+ etc.
  • CanCan - Role-based Authorization (RBA) system that restricts what resources a given user is allowed to access

File/Image Upload

  • CarrierWave - Upload images/files from Rails application

Asset Pipeline

  • Fog - Upload images to cloud
  • Asset Sync - Sync and serve assets from S3, Cloudfront etc.

Pagination

  • Kaminari - Easily create pagination when entries from db queries get too long.

Background Tasks

  • Delayed Job - Execute longer tasks like emailing a long list of entries in the background.

Admin Panels

  • Active Admin - Instantly create an admin panel for your rails app.
  • Rails Admin - Another great admin panel for managing your data

Content Management System

  • RefineryCMS - Popular Rails based CMS

entry.title: Jekyll is up and running
entry.content:
Finally got Jekyll up and running tonight. What is Jekyll you ask? Well, according to its Github page, Jekyll is a simple, blog aware, static site generator. Thats what it does! It takes all the blogposts you write in markdown and generates a static site from them. You can drop the generated files into any web server and you will be able to serve those pages to your reader.

Jekyll is hacker-style blogging. Write your posts in a text editor in markdown, run rake generate, commit your files, and push it to your site's servers. That's how you publish a Jekyll-powered blogpost. The posts are served in .html too, which makes the page load extremely fast!

entry.title: About Yoongfook
entry.content:
I am am an experienced product manager, ruby on rails programmer, front-end designer and startup founder

Product Manager

I am currently a Lean Product Manager at Pollenizer, one of the top startup incubator in Australia. This role has a good overlap between customer development and product management. We use lean startup principles - running experiments, measuring results, hacking growth, agile dev and quick iterations.

Ruby on Rails Programmer

I have been writing apps with Ruby on Rails since 2011 and started doing commercial freelancing work in 2012. The most recent project is Singapore Tender where I implemented a role-based authentication system (Devise, CanCan), account activation system, nested model forms, image uploading (CarrierWave), daily email digests, paypal integration (ActiveMerchant), object-based searching (Ransack), and email campaign integration (Gibbon).

Front-end Designer

I use the latest in CSS technology (SASS - mixins, variables, Twitter Bootstrap, Zurb Foundation), and popular Javascript frameworks (jQuery, Angular JS) to create modern-looking websites at a fraction of the time needed. As the saying goes- don't re-invent the wheel.

Startup Founder

I started 3 businesses in Singapore before moving to Sydney. Tagloop - An online store for pre-programmed NFC stickers, Gspot - A platform for launching referral campaigns on Facebook, and Hastify - An online food delivery website. At Hastify, we managed to raise $50,000 from the Singaporean Government, and subsequently an angel round from one of the founders of Hungrygowhere, the Yelp of Singapore
